prompt:
Australia's waste industry is being undermined by unscrupulous middle-men contracted to shift rubbish interstate to avoid paying landfill levies.

Key points: Organised waste trade avoiding NSW tariffs by dumping in Qld

Qld residents "worried for their health" amid concerns asbestos dumped on vacant sites

Waste illegally dumped on private properties in NSW, Vic

Regulators and governments know about this practice but have repeatedly failed to act.

The Four Corners investigation has exposed an organised network of waste transporting and freighting companies sending waste by road and by rail to Queensland to avoid paying the high New South Wales landfill levy of $138 per tonne.

The trade is so lucrative that the industry estimates the amount of construction and demolition waste now being transported to Queensland has reached about 1 million tonnes a year, almost double official government figures from the past financial year.

It represents around $100 million in revenue lost to NSW Treasury.

The Queensland Newman government abolished Queensland's landfill levy in 2014. Since then, the interstate waste trade has flourished.

It is now cheaper to truck waste to Queensland than it is to dispose of it and pay the levy in the state where it is generated.

Queensland has become known as "the dumping capital of Australia".

Residents 'worried for their health'

Residents in south-east Queensland, where multiple dumps are located, have told Four Corners they are increasingly concerned about what is being tipped down the old mine sites surrounding them.

"We are worried for our health," a group of concerned Queensland residents said.

"We know that there's lots of asbestos that goes in, and when the dumps are closed for the day, people are dumping it on vacant sites when they can't get in [to the landfill]," one Ipswich resident said.

The head of the Australian Council of Recycling, Grant Musgrove, said Queensland residents had a right to be worried about possible impacts on their health.

"They have a right to know, to have transparent process conducted by independent environmental toxicologists to see what impacts there may be," he said.

Illegal dumping to avoid the levy

In NSW and Victoria, another way the landfill levy is being flouted is through illegal dumping operations, where tens of thousands of tonnes of building and demolition waste are being dumped on private properties instead of at licenced landfills.

Four Corners highlighted the case of a large illegal dump right on the banks of the Hawkesbury River in NSW.

An estimated 20,000 tonnes of construction and demolition waste, including asbestos, was dumped on the privately owned land.

The dumpers avoided an estimated $2.6 million in levy fees.

Just as disturbing are allegations aired during an Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) inquiry into corruption in the waste industry that the local council, Gosford, was complicit in illegal dumping at the site.

Gosford Council declined to comment on the allegation due to the investigation.

One document reveals the NSW EPA was aware of a massive illegal dumping operation from January 2015 but failed to intervene and stop it for almost 16 months despite calls for help from residents.

The EPA says it is preparing to prosecute.

Regulators called to account

Industry insiders told Four Corners multiple state regulators were aware of the burgeoning interstate waste trade and illegal dumping but had failed to rein it in, despite calls from within industry to tackle the problem.

The NSW EPA introduced a law in 2014 designed to stop the interstate waste trade, known as the proximity principle.

It was designed to stop waste being moved more than 150 kilometres from where it was generated, but the law was riddled with holes and easily challenged by industry operators seeking to undermine it.

The head of the Waste Contractor and Recyclers Association of NSW, Tony Khoury, told Four Corners the good operators were now going out of business as they were being undercut by companies transporting waste to Queensland

Q: How is the recycling industry in NSW being affected by companies transporting waste to Queensland?

Step 1: Understand the question
Q: How is the recycling industry in NSW being affected by companies transporting waste to Queensland, and why are the good recycling operators struggling?
A: To understand this question, we need to know how the recycling industry works in NSW and what the effects of transporting waste to Queensland are on it.

Step 2: Examine the causes
Companies in Queensland pay less for the recycled materials compared to those in NSW. This means that they can produce goods at lower costs than their counterparts in NSW. Additionally, transportation costs for waste from NSW to Queensland are also relatively low compared to other regions. These factors make it more attractive for companies in Queensland to buy recycled materials instead of using virgin materials. As a result, companies in NSW are losing profits as fewer recyclers continue operating.

Step 3: Analyze the effect on quality operators
High-quality recycling operators who prioritize safety and sustainability often cannot compete with the prices offered by larger companies involved in shipping waste interstate. They have been forced to shut down or sell off their operations. Consequently, there is an increased risk of unregulated or unsafe practices among the remaining operators as competition becomes fiercer. Moreover, reduced competition may drive up costs as the surviving players control market share. In essence, the situation presents challenges to high-quality, ethical operators. 

Step 4: Recommend solutions
To alleviate this challenge, regulatory measures should be put in place such as setting minimum price requirements for recycled materials bought locally and banning waste exports altogether until there is better balance within the local market. Furthermore, government subsidies could support quality operators through tax breaks or direct financial assistance so that small-scale entrepreneurs do not get wiped out by aggressive pricing strategies employed by bigger firms.

Q: How is the recycling industry in NSW being affected by companies transporting waste to Queensland?
Paraphrase: The recycling industry in NSW is negatively impacted by companies transporting waste to Queensland, causing good recycling operators to struggle and go out of business as a result of being undercut by these companies.

Firstly, it's important to understand how the transportation of waste to Queensland is affecting the recycling industry in NSW. When waste is transported out of state, it reduces the amount of material available for local recyclers to process. This means that the remaining materials become less valuable, making it difficult for recycling operators to turn a profit. 
As a result, good recycling operators who prioritize sustainability and proper waste management practices are having trouble competing with companies that are willing to export waste to Queensland for financial gain. These good operators may not have access to the same resources or infrastructure as larger, more established companies, which makes it even harder for them to stay afloat. Ultimately, this has led to some good recycling operators going out of business altogether.

Q. What are the potential consequences of good recycling operators in NSW going out of business due to being undercut by companies transporting waste to Queensland?

 The potential consequences of good recycling operators in NSW going out of business due to being undercut by companies transporting waste to Queensland are:
1. Reduction in recycling capacity: With fewer recycling operators, there will be a decrease in the overall capacity to process and recycle waste materials, leading to an increased reliance on landfilling or exporting waste.
2. Environmental impact: Landfilling or exporting waste instead of recycling can have detrimental environmental effects, such as increased greenhouse gas emissions and pollution from landfill sites.
3. Loss of jobs and economic impact: The closure of recycling operators can result in job losses for workers in the industry, affecting local economies and potentially leading to unemployment and financial strain for individuals and communities.
4. Decreased resource recovery: Good recycling operators play a crucial role in recovering valuable resources from waste. Their closure could lead to a decrease in resource recovery rates, wasting valuable materials that could have been reused or recycled.
5. Increased pressure on remaining operators: With fewer competitors, the remaining recycling operators may face increased demand and workload, potentially compromising their ability to maintain quality standards and meet recycling targets effectively.

Overall, the consequences of good recycling operators going out of business due to undercutting by waste transport companies extend beyond just the industry itself and can impact the environment, economy, job market, and resource recovery efforts.

Title: The Recycling Struggle
Once upon a time in the beautiful state of New South Wales, there was a thriving recycling industry. Good recycling operators worked diligently, turning waste into useful resources, and the community lauded them for their efforts in keeping the environment clean. Possible causes for poor sales include:

1. Competition - When a market is saturated with many similar products or services, it can be challenging for a company to stand out and attract customers. This can result in lower sales as customers have many options to choose from.

2. Pricing - If a company's prices are higher compared to similar products or services in the market, it can deter customers from making purchases. Customers are often motivated by finding good value for their money, so if a company's prices are perceived as too high, it can lead to poor sales.

3. Marketing - Getting the word out about products or services is critical in attracting customers. If a company has inadequate marketing or advertising strategies, or if their marketing efforts do not effectively reach their target audience, it can result in lower sales numbers.

4. Distribution - An effective distribution network is essential in making a company's products readily available to customers. If a company has limited or unreliable distribution methods, it can hinder customers' ability to access their products, resulting in poor sales.

5. Product quality - If a company's products do not meet customer expectations in terms of quality, functionality, or value, it can lead to dissatisfaction and poor sales. Customers are more likely to switch to alternative products that provide a better user experience or better meet their needs.

These factors can individually or collectively contribute to poor sales for a company and must be identified and addressed in order for the company to improve performance and drive stronger sales revenue.

However, our sensitivity to exoplanets is likely limited by stellar activity at the $\sim$1~m~s$^{-1}$ level for most stars \citep[e.g.,][]{Saar.1997,Haywood.2016}.

High-cadence observations present both challenges and opportunities for accurately detecting and characterizing exoplanets during their orbital periods. One challenge is that high-cadence observations may lead to a higher number of noise sources. These noise sources include, but are not limited to, flares, granulation, and spot activity on the host star. These signals can mimic the signal of an Earth-like exoplanet, making it difficult to distinguish between the two.
However, high-cadence observations also present opportunities to study the activity of the host star, which is essential for correcting RV measurements. By observing the spectral lines of the host star, we can measure its activity level and use this information to correct RV measurements for stellar activity signals. This correction process is crucial for detecting Earth-like exoplanets, as their signals are often lost in the noise caused by stellar activity.

And here's an answer that addresses the Q:
"There are several known mechanisms for planet formation, including collisions, accretion, and gravitational instability. Each of these mechanisms can lead to different types of planets in different environments, depending on factors such as their initial conditions and the properties of the star and surrounding disk. Collisions can result in the formation of hot Jupiters, while the accretion of gas and dust can lead to the formation of gaseous planets like Neptune. Gravitational instability tends to lead to the formation of giant planets, but can also result in the creation of exotic objects like brown dwarfs. By studying the characteristics of exoplanets in different environments, we can learn more about how these mechanisms operate and the role they play in the formation of planetary systems."

Current techniques use laser interferometry and optical fiber technology to monitor minuscule changes in distances over long baselines; however, these methods must be carefully calibrated to isolate the weak gravitational signal against external factors such as seismic vibrations, atmospheric fluctuations, and even minute thermal movements inside detectors themselves. Researchers at advanced facilities like LIGO, VIRGO, KAGRA, and GEO600 employ sophisticated software and hardware designs as well as extensive data analysis techniques to extract signals from this "noisy" environment. 
Overcoming these challenges requires constant innovation in experimental and computational methodologies. Developments such as cryogenically cooled laser amplifiers and low-loss mirror coatings help minimize thermal disturbances while advances in quantum optics and adaptive control algorithms enable more precise signal processing. Further improvements in computer simulations, statistical inference tools, and machine learning algorithms are also essential for identifying, validating, and characterizing faint gravitational wave signatures among increasingly complex data sets. Ultimately, sustained international collaboration and knowledge sharing across academic institutions, laboratories, and organizations are vital components of solving the intricate puzzle presented by gravitational waves and the fascinating astrophysical phenomena they reveal.

How can high-cadence observations help in understanding and correcting for non-planetary radial velocity (RV) signals induced by stellar activity?

 High-cadence observations offer several advantages in the study of non-planetary RV signals induced by stellar activity. By observing a planet throughout its full orbit, high-cadence observations allow researchers to capture the variations in RV measurements caused by both planetary and non-planetary signals. This comprehensive dataset enables a deeper understanding of the complex interactions between stellar activity and RV measurements. Additionally, high cadence allows for the identification of periodic patterns in the RV data, which can help distinguish between planetary and non-planetary signals. Furthermore, high-cadence observations provide opportunities to analyze short-term variations in stellar activity that may affect RV measurements, improving our ability to correct for these effects. Overall, high-cadence observations play a crucial role in unraveling the influence of stellar activity on RV measurements and enhancing our ability to accurately detect and characterize exoplanets.

Sure, here are my thoughts on the challenges and opportunities presented by high-cadence observations for accurately detecting and characterizing exoplanets during their orbital periods:

Challenges:

1. Stellar activity: One of the biggest challenges is stellar activity, which can introduce non-planetary RV signals or noise that can interfere with detecting and characterizing exoplanets. Fluctuations in brightness or emission lines due to starspots, granulation, or other sources of activity can mask or mimic planetary signals, making it difficult to distinguish between the two.
2. Correcting for non-planetary signals: To accurately detect and characterize exoplanets, we need to correct for non-planetary RV signals induced by stellar activity. This requires a deep understanding of the stellar activity and its influence on the RV measurements, which can be a complex and challenging task.

Opportunities:

1. Orbital phase coverage: High-cadence observations provide opportunities to observe the planet throughout its full orbit, allowing us to capture a more complete picture of its behavior and characteristics. By measuring the RV curve over an entire orbit, we can uncover information about the planet's mass, orbital radius, and inclination angle, among other parameters.
2. Time series analysis: With high-cadence observations, we can perform time series analysis to identify periodicities in the RV signal that may indicate the presence of an exoplanet. Moreover, this approach allows us to measure tiny variations in the RV signal that would otherwise be undetectable with lower sampling rates.
3. Planetary signature refinement: High-cadence observations can help refine the planetary signature in the RV data by reducing the noise introduced by stellar activity. As a result, we can achieve higher accuracy in determining the properties of the exoplanet and improve our ability to differentiate between genuine planetary signals and non-planetary RV noise.

In conclusion, while high-cadence observations present significant challenges related to stellar activity and correcting for non-planetary signals, they also offer valuable opportunities for capturing a more complete picture of exoplanet behavior and characteristics.

The color-magnitude diagram (CMD) analysis depends on the photometric data quality in several ways:

Accuracy of the photometry: Poorer photometry will lead to larger uncertainties in the measured magnitudes, which may affect the shape of the CMD and make it harder to identify subtle features like star clusters or the tip of the red giant branch.

Photometric depth: Deeper photometry generally provides better sensitivity to faint objects, which can help reveal more information about the underlying stellar populations. However, it's important to note that very deep photometry can also be more susceptible to issues like crowding and dust extinction.

Calibration errors: If the photometry is not properly calibrated, the measured magnitudes may not accurately reflect the true brightness of the stars. Calibration errors can arise from imperfections in the detector or telescope optics, as well as incorrect assumptions about the sky background or atmospheric transmission.

In addition, the accuracy of the CMD analysis also depends on the number of stars analyzed. Larger samples provide more statistical power, allowing for finer resolution of the features in the CMD and a more robust estimation of the error bars. However, if the sample size is too small, then the CMD may be dominated by noise and not show any clear patterns at all. In general, the optimal sample size will depend on the particular science goals of the analysis and the expected number of stars in the target region.

The study of MHD is an essential tool for understanding many astrophysical phenomena. Some of these include:
1. Star Formation: MHD plays a critical role in the process of star formation. Huge clouds of gas and dust in space collapses under its own gravity to form stars. However, this collapse is resisted by the pressure of the gas. To overcome this resistance, MHD processes come into play. These models also show how the magnetic field may have evolved over time.
3. Accretion Disks: Whenever matter falls onto a compact object, such as a star or a black hole, it forms an accretion disk. In these disks, MHD processes play a major role in transporting energy and angular momentum. For example, viscous forces cause the disk to become thinner and hotter as material spirals inwards. This heating can be due to friction between the moving particles or through the dissipation of MHD turbulence. The resulting outflows from the accretion disk power quasars, active galactic nuclei, and gamma-ray bursts.

Answer:Some of the challenges faced by researchers in detecting and interpreting gravitational waves include minimizing background noise and finding consistent signals amid large amounts of data. Current techniques use laser interferometry and optical fiber technology to monitor minuscule changes in distances over long baselines; however, these methods must be carefully calibrated to isolate the weak gravitational signal against external factors such as seismic vibrations, atmospheric fluctuations, and even minute thermal movements inside detectors themselves. Researchers at advanced facilities like LIGO, VIRGO, KAGRA, and GEO600 employ sophisticated software and hardware designs as well as extensive data analysis techniques to extract signals from this "noisy" environment. 
Overcoming these challenges requires constant innovation in experimental and computational methodologies. Developments such as cryogenically cooled laser amplifiers and low-loss mirror coatings help minimize thermal disturbances while advances in quantum optics and adaptive control algorithms enable more precise signal processing. Further improvements in computer simulations, statistical inference tools, and machine learning algorithms are also essential for identifying, validating, and characterizing faint gravitational wave signatures among increasingly complex data sets. Ultimately, sustained international collaboration and knowledge sharing across academic institutions, laboratories, and organizations are vital components of solving the intricate puzzle presented by gravitational waves and the fascinating astrophysical phenomena they reveal.

Answer:The study of MHD is an essential tool for understanding many astrophysical phenomena. Some of these include:
1. Star Formation: MHD plays a critical role in the process of star formation. Huge clouds of gas and dust in space collapses under its own gravity to form stars. However, this collapse is resisted by the pressure of the gas. To overcome this resistance, MHD processes come into play. For example, the amplification of magnetic fields during the collapse helps to support the cloud against further gravitational infall. This allows the cloud to fragment into smaller clumps which can then serve as seeds for the formation of new stars.
2. Planetary Magnetic Fields: The Earth has a global magnetic field that protects the planet from harmful solar winds and cosmic rays. This magnetic field is generated by convection in the outer core of the Earth. MHD models have been used to study how the motion of liquid metal in the core can generate the Earth’s magnetic field. These models also show how the magnetic field may have evolved over time.
3. Accretion Disks: Whenever matter falls onto a compact object, such as a star or a black hole, it forms an accretion disk. In these disks, MHD processes play a major role in transporting energy and angular momentum. For example, viscous forces cause the disk to become thinner and hotter as material spirals inwards. This heating can be due to friction between the moving particles or through the dissipation of MHD turbulence. The resulting outflows from the accretion disk power quasars, active galactic nuclei, and gamma-ray bursts.

It was a powerful tool for pricing options, which are financial instruments that give the holder the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a certain price at or before a certain date.
The FMLS model had a unique feature where the second-order spatial derivative in the standard Black-Scholes (BS) equation was replaced by an $\alpha$-order spatial derivative with $\alpha \in (1, 2]$. This meant that the fractional-order derivative at a point was not just a property of the function at that point, but also depended on information from a subset of the entire domain of definition. This made the model more complex and difficult to work with.

\section{Introduction}


The celebrated Black--Scholes (BS) model is based on the assumption that the underlying asset price follows a geometric Brownian motion \cite{black1973pricing}. 
However, it is well documented in the literature that the BS model usually underestimates the probability of the appearance of jumps or large movements of stock prices over small time steps~\cite{CW};
for example, when analyzing the S\&P 500 data, a ``leptokurtic distribution'' is observed, which has a higher peak and two heavier tails than those of the normal distribution.
Many efforts have been made to develop mathematical models that capable of capturing the leptokurtic feature observed in financial market data.
A feasible approach is to adopt a L\'evy process extending Brownian motion for the description of the price, such as the Press model~\cite{press1967compound}, Merton's jump diffusion model~\cite{Mer}, and so on.
This idea allows us to model large price changes due to sudden exogenous events or information, and can explain some systematic empirical biases with respect to the BS model.

Among all the L\'evy process models, the finite moment log-stable (FMLS) process model, proposed by Carr and Wu~\cite{CW}, can not only successfully capture the high-frequency empirical probability distribution of the S\&P 500 data, 
but also fit simultaneously volatility smirks at different maturities. 
Most importantly, in contrast to many other L\'evy process models, 
the FMLS model ensures the finiteness of all moments of the underlying index level and the existence of an equivalent martingale measure. 
This paper is carried out under the framework of the FMLS model. 
The extension of our approach and results to other L\'evy processes models (e.g., KoBol and CGMY mentioned in~\cite{CCN}) is quite promising.

Mathematically, the key tool to characterize the non-locality induced by the pure jumps under the FMLS model is the fractional partial differential equation (FPDE), which is a subset of the class of pseudo-differential equations. 
In the new FPDE associated with the FMLS model, the second-order spatial derivative involved in the standard BS equation is replaced by an $\alpha$-order spatial derivative with $\alpha\in(1, 2]$. 
In comparison to the derivative of integer order, the fractional-order derivative at a point not only involves properties of the function at that particular point, but also the information of the function in a certain subset of the entire domain of definition. 
This global dependency of the fractional derivative has added an additional degree of difficulty when either analytical methods or the numerical simulations are attempted. 

Under the FMLS model, many techniques have been developed to compute option values, as summarized in \cite{schmelzle2010option}.
Cartea and del-Castillo-Negrete~\cite{CCN} considered the pricing of barrier options under the FMLS model purely numerically, by using a finite difference method.
Recently, Chen et al.~\cite{CXZ1} derived closed-form analytical solutions for European-style options under the same model, which is one of the main tools in our approach.
In contrast, pricing American options is more complicated even in the classical BS model~\cite{huang1996pricing,ju1998pricing,longstaff2001valuing,Zhu}, 
with challenge mainly stemming from the nonlinearity originated from the inherent characteristic that an American option can be exercised at any time during its lifespan. 
This additional right casts the American option pricing problem into a free boundary problem, which is highly nonlinear and far more difficult to deal with.
Several numerical scheme for pricing American options were proposed in \cite{CXZ,chen2014penalty,chen2015finite} under the FMLS model.

The purpose of this paper is to investigate analytic properties of American options under the FMLS model.
This topic has been extensively studied in the literature under the standard BS model. 
For example, Ekstr\"om \cite{EE1} proved that the price of an American put is convex with respect the underlying price  (see also El Karoui et al. \cite{El} and Hobson \cite{Hob} for related results),
and convexity of the optimal exercise boundary for an American put was obtained by Ekstr\"om \cite{EE2} and Chen et al.~\cite{CCJZ}.
Those properties can help us understand the asymptotic
behavior of the optimal exercise boundary near expiry \cite{CCJZ}

Step 1: Understanding American Options and FMLS Model
American options are a type of financial instrument that gives the holder the right to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price (strike price) before a specified date (expiration date). Step 2: Analytic Properties of American Options under FMLS Model
The analytic properties of American options under the FMLS model include:
* Closed-form solutions for the option prices and Greeks (sensitivities of the option price to changes in the underlying asset price, volatility, interest rates, and time)
* Ability to handle complex payoff functions and underlying asset dynamics
* Accurate pricing of options with underlying assets that follow stochastic vol

Original Question: Can you explain the difference between transfer learning and fine-tuning in natural language processing?

Step 1: Define Transfer Learning
Transfer learning is a technique in machine learning where a model trained on one task is repurposed or adapted for another related task. In NLP, this often involves taking a pre-trained language model and modifying it slightly before training it on a new task. By starting with a pre-existing language model, we can avoid having to train a new model from scratch and instead focus on fine-tuning the existing model to suit our needs.

Step 2: Define Fine-Tuning
Fine-tuning is a type of transfer learning where a pre-trained language model is modified and then trained on a new task with a relatively small amount of data. Instead of starting from scratch, we take advantage of the knowledge already embedded in the pre-trained model and adjust it to fit the new task.

Step 3: Compare and Contrast
While transfer learning and fine-tuning share many similarities, they differ in their approach to adapting pre-trained models for new tasks. Transfer learning generally involves larger modifications to the original model, whereas fine-tuning involves more subtle changes to better align the pre-trained model with the target task. prompt:
Was pointed today to this interview with developmental psychologist Lisa Diamond, on the subject of sexuality, and additionally, whether it matters whether people who identify as gay or bisexual are “born that way” or not. She takes the position that ultimately it really doesn’t matter:

It is time to just take the whole idea of sexuality as immutable, the born this way notion, and just come to a consensus as scientists and as legal scholars that we need to put it to rest. It’s unscientific, it’s unnecessary and it’s unjust. It doesn’t matter how we got to be this way. As a scientist, I think it’s one of the most fascinating questions out there and one that I will continue to investigate. As a lesbian and a progressive, I think it’s totally irrelevant and just politics.

I don’t know if in fact Diamond is correct, but I’ll note that for a very long time now I’ve personally held the position that I don’t care why or if someone decides to love someone of the same sex (physically and/or emotionally and all the stuff in between), simply that if they do, that love should be respected, legally and socially. I think it’s entirely possible that some people are “born that way,” that some people become that way through environment (Diamond notes that “environment” should be considered a term rather more expansive than “how you grew up and with whom”), and that others might have become so by a combination of both, or some other factor entirely. Ultimately it doesn’t matter, outside of a dry and somewhat abstract set of academic questions. However you got there, you got there.

Diamond also talks about sexual fluidity, which “means that people are born with a sexual orientation and also with a degree of sexual flexibility,” which is to say (at least as I understand it), you know your general sexuality, and you also know how much leeway you give yourself inside of that understanding. So for example you might identify as straight but be willing to acknowledge that every once in a while you find someone of the same sex attractive, or gay but with occasional hetero crushes, or bisexual but with a lean one way more than another on average. Or, you know, you might identify as something rather more expansive than that.

This also makes a great deal of sense to me. People have been talking about the Kinsey scale for years, but I find that sort of linear sexuality tracking a little limiting. I picture it as multidimensional with a number of axes: Gay-straight might be one; sexual-asexual might be another; conservative – opportunistic might be a third. A guy who is largely straight but highly sexual and somewhat opportunistic might not turn down a same-sex encounter because, hey, sex; another man who is gay but closer to asexual and conservative might turn down the same opportunity.

These three axes are not necessarily the complete set, I would note; likewise I would note that not every dimension of sexuality has the same range on every person. And finally, of course, one’s understanding of one’s sexuality may change over time — again for various reasons.

All of which is to say, sexuality: There’s some complex shit going down there.

And all the more reason, from the point of view of social and legal acceptance, not to actually care how someone arrived at their sexuality. The law should care if sexual encounters are consensual; society should discourage (to use a word mildly) non-consensual encounters

How can we foster a more inclusive and accepting society for LGBTQ+ individuals in Saudi Arabia?

 Fostering a more inclusive and accepting society for LGBTQ+ individuals in Saudi Arabia requires a multi-faceted approach. Firstly, there needs to be education and awareness campaigns to challenge the prevailing stigma and misconceptions surrounding LGBTQ+ identities. This includes providing accurate information about sexual orientation and gender identity, dispelling myths, and promoting empathy and understanding.

Secondly, legal reforms are crucial to protect the rights of LGBTQ+ individuals. Advocacy efforts should focus on decriminalizing same-sex relationships, ensuring legal recognition of gender identity for transgender individuals, and implementing anti-discrimination laws that explicitly include sexual orientation and gender identity as protected characteristics.

Thirdly, creating safe spaces and support networks is essential. Establishing LGBTQ+ community centers or organizations can provide resources, counseling services, and a sense of belonging for individuals who may feel isolated or marginalized.

Lastly, engaging with religious leaders and institutions can play a significant role in challenging homophobic attitudes within Saudi Arabian society. Encouraging dialogue between religious leaders and LGBTQ+ activists can help bridge the gap between religious teachings and acceptance of diverse sexual orientations and gender identities.

By combining these strategies - education, legal reforms, safe spaces, and interfaith dialogue - we can work towards fostering a more inclusive society where LGBTQ+ individuals in Saudi Arabia are respected, protected, and able to live authentically without fear of persecution or discrimination.

prompt:
Russian opposition leader Aleksei Navalny and several members of his Anticorruption Foundation (FBK) were attacked by Cossacks at an airport in the southern Black Sea resort city of Anapa on May 17.

Videos show Navalny and about 30 FBK members walking toward the airport when they encounter a group of men wearing Cossack hats and uniforms.

Navalny and other FBK members are doused with milk and verbally berated before a line of Cossacks attempt to block their path to the airport and a standoff ensues, with Navalny supporters trying to form a protective ring around the opposition leader.

After an FBK supporter appears to elbow a man, a melee breaks out and several FBK members -- many of them wearing large backpacks -- are punched, kicked, and thrown to the ground.​

Navalny wrote on Twitter that the attackers beat both men and women, and mocked police for failing to protect him and his team.

"You see how many police are usually at every airport? And here, especially in May, at the Anapa airport, two police officers for the entire airport," he wrote in one tweet.

Anapa police told TASS that no arrests had been made. The official state news agency also cited the leader of the Cossack Unit in Anapa, Valery Plotnikov, as saying that Cossacks were attempting to separate two conflicting groups when an FBK member was hit with milk, causing members of the foundation to retaliate.

Plotnikov claimed that members of Navalny's group beat two civilians, both of whom were taken to hospital, one with a broken nose.

One Cossack who participated in the action reportedly said that the original plan to hurl milk at Navalny and his supporters changed after an elderly Cossack was elbowed.

"The fight broke out because of that blow," Dmitry Slaboda told the Govorit Moskva radio station, according to Reuters. "We just wanted to show them that there is no room here for Navalny, who lives on American money."

Among his string of tweets pertaining to the incident, Navalny mocked suggestions that FBK members had initiated the violence.

"'Cossacks attacked the FBK'" -- that is just factually incorrect. The police and 'Cossacks' carried the attack out. The organizer (of the attack) is, of course, the state."

In other tweets he accused police of following him and his group during their stay in the Krasnodar region.

Artyom Torchinsky, a Navalny associate who is also a journalist for Dozhd TV, was taken to hospital with a head injury. Torchinsky told Dozhd TV from the hospital by phone that the assailants attacked the FBK members for no reason and shouted: "Get off of our land!"

FBK spokeswoman Kira Yarmysh wrote on Twitter that Navalny and some 30 members of his foundation traveled to Anapa to hold team-building exercises in the countryside outside the city located in Russia's southern Krasnodar region.

Navalny said earlier that local police in the region had detained him and his associates for several hours on May 13. Local authorities said that Navalny and his team were not detained, but just checked as part of a security campaign.

Cossacks, people of mixed Turkic and Slavic background, have longstanding ties to Russia's southern regions and were historically used as mercenaries by Russian tsars.

After being persecuted and banned across the Soviet Union, Cossacks have been allowed by Russian authorities to revive their traditions and have been used in a semiofficial capacity in their Krasnodar stronghold to enforce law and order.

Many Kremlin critics consider Cossacks' involvement in law enforcement illegal and say they are used as an instrument to crack down on dissent. In February 2014, Cossacks providing security for the Sochi Winter Olympics whipped members of the anti-Kremlin punk-performance collective Pussy Riot.

Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told journalists in Moscow on May 17 that he was unable to comment on the incident in Anapa.

"I would not like to make conclusions on something based on information from a single source," Peskov said.

With reporting by RFE/RL's Russian Service, tvrain

"It's great to have Jamie commit to Brisbane Roar," Aloisi said.

"He is a Brisbane boy who loves the club and what the Roar stands for.

"We rate Jamie highly as a professional and as a goalkeeper and we look forward to his ongoing contribution to the long-term future we are building at the club."

Young, 30, has played 37 Hyundai A-League games for the Roar over the last two seasons and 44 appearances across all competitions.

He started in 13 consecutive games this season from Round 3 until last weekend when he sat on the bench against Adelaide United with Michael Theo recalled after completing his rehab from a quad muscle injury.

Young said the competition for the goalkeeping starting spot was bringing out the best in both keepers and was one of the reasons he re-signed with the Roar.

"With playing the games I've had, it was a no-brainer, it's the icing on the cake," Young said tonight.

"It secures my future and the confidence that the club has invested in my career is so positive."

Young praised Roar goalkeeping coach Jason Kearton and the support and competition from Theo for helping him take his skills to new levels.

"Jason has spent countless hours just tweaking my game . . . I think we can all agree that has paid dividends," Young said

Four years before the world-famous Stonewall riots, these were two of the first gay rights protests held in the United States. That same year, Allen Ginsberg was expelled from Cuba for spreading rumors that Raul Castro—Fidel’s brother and successor as president—was gay and claiming that Guevara was “cute.”

This case has significant implications for future cases where trademarks are deemed too generic or descriptive because it sets a precedent for determining when a term becomes part of the public domain and cannot be registered as a trademark. Here is how I would break down my thoughts on this matter:

1. Generic terms are not eligible for trademark protection: One important takeaway from this case is that generic terms cannot be protected under trademark law. This makes sense since such terms are commonly used to describe a particular product or service and do not serve to distinguish one provider from another. If someone tries to monopolize a generic term through trademark registration, they will likely face opposition in subsequent cases.
2. Descriptive terms require secondary meaning: For terms that are merely descriptive (i.e., they directly describe a feature or characteristic of the goods or services), they can only be protected if they have acquired what is known as "secondary meaning." Essentially, this means that consumers have come to associate the term with a single source or brand over time. However, if a term is deemed too descriptive at the outset, it may face difficulty acquiring secondary meaning and thus may also struggle to receive trademark protection.
3. Context matters: Another crucial factor courts consider is the context in which a term is used. In the case of "I Believe That We Will Win!", the court determined that the phrase had become intertwined with US Soccer's identity and was being used as an informational and aspirational slogan. As such, it did not function as a traditional trademark but instead served a different purpose. Courts will continue to examine the manner in which a contested term is employed to determine its true nature.

Answer:This case has significant implications for future cases where trademarks are deemed too generic or descriptive because it sets a precedent for determining when a term becomes part of the public domain and cannot be registered as a trademark. Here is how I would break down my thoughts on this matter:

1. Generic terms are not eligible for trademark protection: One important takeaway from this case is that generic terms cannot be protected under trademark law. This makes sense since such terms are commonly used to describe a particular product or service and do not serve to distinguish one provider from another. If someone tries to monopolize a generic term through trademark registration, they will likely face opposition in subsequent cases.
2. Descriptive terms require secondary meaning: For terms that are merely descriptive (i.e., they directly describe a feature or characteristic of the goods or services), they can only be protected if they have acquired what is known as "secondary meaning." Essentially, this means that consumers have come to associate the term with a single source or brand over time. However, if a term is deemed too descriptive at the outset, it may face difficulty acquiring secondary meaning and thus may also struggle to receive trademark protection.
3. Context matters: Another crucial factor courts consider is the context in which a term is used. In the case of "I Believe That We Will Win!", the court determined that the phrase had become intertwined with US Soccer's identity and was being used as an informational and aspirational slogan. As such, it did not function as a traditional trademark but instead served a different purpose. Courts will continue to examine the manner in which a contested term is employed to determine its true nature.
